subject: Re: Question about how to test data
msgSnippet: Hi Lasse, Thanks for your response.  Yes, you are right.  I suppose that is it...I want to verify the rows in the spreadsheet against the rows in that
messageBody:
Hi Lasse,

Thanks for your response. Yes, you are right. I suppose that is
it...I want to verify the rows in the spreadsheet against the rows in
that table....and report on any inconsistencies. That would do it.

Testing the application...written in Java/J2EE, exposed as Axis web
services...I am comfortable writing JUnit or Cactus tests in that
context. I guess the new challenge ... for me ... is the Excel
spreadsheet. How do I get at it from Java APIs? I will do some
online research and googling into that....or listen to any ideas from
this group on how to go about that.

And then the JDBC calls to the table...I think I can figure that out.

This whole thing...spreadsheet rows comparison to database table....I
think I can re-use this pattern in several places. I will keep the
group updated as I make progress if there is interest.

Thanks for your help,

Mike





--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Lasse Koskela" <lasse.koskela@...>
wrote:
>
> Hi Mike,
>
> On Dec 12, 2007 10:47 PM, Mike Foley <mike_foley_01612@...> wrote:
> > I guess my problem statement is this: the business analysts have
an
> > Excel spreadsheet with hundreds of rows...each row defines some
unique
> > requirement on the way this particular thing is supposed to
work. Each
> > row in this spreadsheet, each requirement if you will, is not
> > implemented in code.....but in data...which I am calling
reference data
> > or meta data....in this table.
>
> Would it make sense to have an automated test compare the rows in
the
> Excel sheet to the rows in the database table?
>
> Lasse
>
> --
> Lasse Koskela
> * Author of "Test Driven" (Manning Publications, 2007) *
> * Reaktor Innovations * http://www.ri.fi/en *
>
